awd_titl_txt: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track A: Enhancing Oklahoma Community Climate Resilience Through Electric School Bus Integration into Local Energy Grids
awd_abstract_narration:
Oklahoma faces frequent extreme weather events like tornadoes and storms, disrupting the state's energy grid. This project seeks to enhance community resilience against climate and environmental instabilities by integrating the Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) technology equipped with electric school buses (ESBs) into Oklahoma energy grids. V2G technology allows these ESBs to supply power back to the grid, offering a sustainable energy solution. This initiative aims to flip the community-university dynamic and empower civic partners to co-design a research-to-innovation solution to improving grid stability during emergencies, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and promote public health. By showcasing the benefits of V2G in a real-world setting, the project could serve as a model for other regions. This work aligns with NSF’s mission to promote the progress of science by investing in research to expand knowledge in science, engineering and education. This work is not only critical for addressing immediate climate-related challenges but also for building a resilient and sustainable future for communities.

The project will integrate V2G-equipped electric school buses (ESBs) into Oklahoma’s energy grid to enhance community resilience to climate disasters such as tornados and storms. In Stage 1, a Community Advisory Board (CAB) with stakeholders from Public Schools, Oklahoma Gas & Electric, Association of Central Oklahoma Governments, Indian Nations Council of Governments, City of Oklahoma City, ESB Manufacturers and other community partners will co-design the research plan, set goals, and refine research questions. Preliminary testing and data collection will be conducted to understand community needs and technical requirements. In Stage 2, field tests and simulations will assess the effectiveness of V2G technology during power outages and peak demand. The project will analyze economic and environmental benefits, including cost savings and reduced greenhouse gas emissions, and develop a decision-making support platform for policymakers. By leveraging civic partners’ expertise, the project aims to create a scalable model for community resilience through innovative energy solutions.

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program’s Track A. Climate and Environmental Instability - Building Resilient Communities through Co-Design, Adaption, and Mitigation and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Oklahoma faces frequent severe weather events, including tornadoes, storms, and heatwaves, leading to widespread power outages and disruptions. Our project, "Recharge-OK," addressed these challenges by exploring how Electric School Buses (ESBs), equipped with Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) technology, can enhance energy resilience in local communities.

Our team successfully formed a Community Advisory Board (CAB) comprising diverse civic partners, including Shawnee Public Schools, Gordon Cooper Technology Center, Oklahoma Gas & Electric (OG&E), Association of Central Oklahoma Governments (ACOG), Indian Nations Council of Governments (INCOG), City of Oklahoma City Office of Sustainability, IC Bus (ESB manufacturer), InCharge Energy (bi-directional charger developer), and academic institutions such as the University of Oklahoma Health Sciences (OUHSC), Oklahoma State University (OSU), and University of Oklahoma (OU). These partners provided strategic guidance for integrating ESBs with local power grids. We completed comprehensive feasibility studies and community assessments, revealing significant potential for ESBs to stabilize energy supply during emergencies and peak demand. Technical analyses conducted by our team showed ESBs, with their large battery capacities (up to 315 kWh per bus), could effectively store renewable energy overnight and discharge it during peak hours or outages. This capability not only boosts energy resilience but also supports grid stability and renewable energy use.

Through extensive community engagement, including nine structured community meetings, workshops, training sessions for emergency responders, and educational outreach to schools, Recharge-OK significantly raised public awareness about sustainable energy solutions and disaster preparedness. Over 60 community members actively participated in various project activities, fostering greater understanding and trust in V2G technology.

Beyond logistical coordination, the project creatively enhanced its visibility and outreach by developing a distinctive project logo, an engaging theme song, and an interactive project website. The website served as a central resource hub, providing project updates, meeting documentation, technical resources, and stakeholder engagement materials, effectively unifying messaging and broadening public engagement. Additionally, a project satisfaction survey was conducted to gauge community feedback and perceptions regarding V2G technology implementation. Survey results indicated high levels of satisfaction, with 83–92% of respondents reporting "extremely satisfied" and 8–17% "somewhat satisfied" across evaluation categories including overall satisfaction, alignment with community needs, innovation in addressing urgent challenges, quality of information shared, and readiness for future project phases.

Our initiative also laid the groundwork for scalable applications beyond Shawnee, Oklahoma. The findings, technical manuals, decision-support platform prototypes, and community engagement strategies developed during this stage are readily adaptable by other communities across Oklahoma and nationwide.

Summary of Key Outcomes:

  • Established robust partnerships among civic organizations, educational institutions, utilities, and local government agencies.
  • Completed technical assessments confirming the viability and benefits of integrating V2G-equipped ESBs into the local energy grid.
  • Enhanced community capacity and readiness through comprehensive training and educational outreach programs.
  • Developed and piloted an initial digital decision-making platform prototype to assist communities in adopting sustainable and resilient energy solutions.
  • Increased community engagement and awareness regarding climate resilience and renewable energy applications, notably in vulnerable and underserved populations.

Recharge-OK demonstrated the tangible benefits of community-driven, renewable energy solutions, enhancing Oklahoma’s resilience against climate-related disruptions and providing a replicable model for communities nationwide.

 


Last Modified: 04/11/2025
Modified by: Hongwan Li

por.por_txt_cntn:
Oklahoma faces frequent severe weather events, including tornadoes, storms, and heatwaves, leading to widespread power outages and disruptions. Our project, "Recharge-OK," addressed these challenges by exploring how Electric School Buses (ESBs), equipped with Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) technology, can enhance energy resilience in local communities.


Our team successfully formed a Community Advisory Board (CAB) comprising diverse civic partners, including Shawnee Public Schools, Gordon Cooper Technology Center, Oklahoma Gas & Electric (OG&E), Association of Central Oklahoma Governments (ACOG), Indian Nations Council of Governments (INCOG), City of Oklahoma City Office of Sustainability, IC Bus (ESB manufacturer), InCharge Energy (bi-directional charger developer), and academic institutions such as the University of Oklahoma Health Sciences (OUHSC), Oklahoma State University (OSU), and University of Oklahoma (OU). Technical analyses conducted by our team showed ESBs, with their large battery capacities (up to 315 kWh per bus), could effectively store renewable energy overnight and discharge it during peak hours or outages. This capability not only boosts energy resilience but also supports grid stability and renewable energy use.


Through extensive community engagement, including nine structured community meetings, workshops, training sessions for emergency responders, and educational outreach to schools, Recharge-OK significantly raised public awareness about sustainable energy solutions and disaster preparedness. Over 60 community members actively participated in various project activities, fostering greater understanding and trust in V2G technology.


Beyond logistical coordination, the project creatively enhanced its visibility and outreach by developing a distinctive project logo, an engaging theme song, and an interactive project website. The website served as a central resource hub, providing project updates, meeting documentation, technical resources, and stakeholder engagement materials, effectively unifying messaging and broadening public engagement. Additionally, a project satisfaction survey was conducted to gauge community feedback and perceptions regarding V2G technology implementation. Survey results indicated high levels of satisfaction, with 8392% of respondents reporting "extremely satisfied" and 817% "somewhat satisfied" across evaluation categories including overall satisfaction, alignment with community needs, innovation in addressing urgent challenges, quality of information shared, and readiness for future project phases.


Our initiative also laid the groundwork for scalable applications beyond Shawnee, Oklahoma. The findings, technical manuals, decision-support platform prototypes, and community engagement strategies developed during this stage are readily adaptable by other communities across Oklahoma and nationwide.


Summary of Key Outcomes:

Established      robust partnerships among civic organizations, educational institutions,      utilities, and local government agencies.
Completed      technical assessments confirming the viability and benefits of integrating      V2G-equipped ESBs into the local energy grid.
Enhanced      community capacity and readiness through comprehensive training and      educational outreach programs.
Developed      and piloted an initial digital decision-making platform prototype to      assist communities in adopting sustainable and resilient energy solutions.
Increased      community engagement and awareness regarding climate resilience and      renewable energy applications, notably in vulnerable and underserved      populations.



Recharge-OK demonstrated the tangible benefits of community-driven, renewable energy solutions, enhancing Oklahomas resilience against climate-related disruptions and providing a replicable model for communities nationwide.
